I had this game on my radar for a long time. I finally got to it and I don't know how to rate it.

The story is pretty boring; the characters AND the zombies are gamefied stereotypes. The zombies are called "freakers" (which feels goofy every time it's said - and it comes up a LOT.) There's a screamer that attracts friends, a bullet sponge tank, fast agile ambush ones. You know. Innovative stuff like that. I'll give it points for not having a spitter archetype.

The main character is an awkward, selfish boner that you'll probably not like as a person. He has a looping arc. It goes: He wants something, a friend of his takes an L, and then he gets exactly what he wants. Throughout this arc the vengeful bad-ass post apocalypse biker will brag about how many freakers he's killed, but is a stammering stuttering mess who never has confidence. It's a bizarre dichotomy. I think they were constantly reminding themselves when writing the MC that it's gotta be REAL but they had forgotten who he is and what we've done in his shoes. It feels neurotic and pulls you away from any immersion or sympathizing.

I made the mistake of playing on survival mode. Driving around on the bike *was* fun briefly, but not when you're made to do it for 60 hours. Constantly refuelling and repairing after a 2.5 minute drive isn't immersive or real, it's tedium. It makes you NOT want to use it. 4 hours in I had already regretted not having fast travel. "Survival" doesn't have anything to do with actually surviving, it just turns off your HUD and annoys you.

The quests are intertwined for the most part and all very repetitive. You'll be doing the same tracking tutorial, clearing the same ambush camp, and rescuing the same potato headed survivor on repeat for as long as you play the game.

I had several bugs that forced game reloads/restarts.

There [i]seems[/i] to be an in game timer where a [i]random[/i] attack will happen to you. Over the course of playing I could feel when I was going to be ambushed by wild life or a special "freaker". At first you'll be like "what the hell, silent wolves!" and then you'll end up thinking "well it's been one cut-scene and 6 minutes of driving so I'm due for a stealth bear covered in barbed wire." I started faking refuelling my bike in those times because you know, the surprise is coming. Oh boy.

I liked killing hordes of zombies a lot - initially a scary and daunting challenge, then a late-game power fantasy. It felt good to have the character progress in that way. The music was well done, shifting appropriately to the action. Graphically it was decent. Cut-scenes would often have one out of place low res texture that ended up pretty comical but I can look past that. 

When out in the world if you 360 your camera at any point you will see enemies of one sort or another. Story-line rides with NPCs seem to have no enemies which seems to be a world-rule-breaking thing. It segues in to my next point.

I enjoyed the open world a lot, but with an asterisk. When you're out and exploring it really feels like an apocalyptic rural mountain area. That feeling is destroyed as soon as you get to a mission. Why is the apocalypse filled with chest high walls for cover in every game?! There are so many survivor camps where you walk through what looks like a paintball arena full of health and ammo. You KNOW you're going to be shooting your way through this after the impending cut-scene. 

It's the inconsistent feeling of being immersed and having it shattered that makes me not want to recommend the game. It's not bad. It's just not enough fun, or immersive enough. It tries to tick all the boxes and ends up not satisfying. The game is simultaneously both too much of a game and not enough of one.

It's not bad.. it just.. is.

Maybe it's for you, but it certainly isn't for me - and definitely not at full price. There's a lot of game time to be had for the money. However that time is both awkward and mostly a chore. Wait for a sale if you're tickled to try it.

You have a wide range of weapons including melee, sidearm, primary and special.  (includes a crossbow special weapon as well)

Days Gone Review

In the hauntingly beautiful landscape of the Pacific Northwest lies a world ravaged by a global pandemic. Days Gone introduces players to a post-apocalyptic vision of Oregon, where humanity struggles to survive amidst the ruins of civilization. Developed by Bend Studio, this open-world action-adventure game plunges players into the shoes of Deacon St. John, a former biker turned drifter, navigating the perilous wilderness on his motorcycle. As Deacon's story unfolds, players will encounter a vast and dynamic open world, teeming with wildlife, hostile enemies, and hidden treasures waiting to be discovered. Whether racing through abandoned highways on his trusty motorcycle, scavenging for supplies in derelict towns, or engaging in intense combat against overwhelming odds, Deacon's journey will test his resilience, courage, and humanity in ways he never imagined.


GAMEPLAY (9.5/10):
As Deacon St. John, players must navigate the harsh wilderness of the Pacific Northwest, scavenging for resources, managing inventory, and crafting essential items to survive. From finding fuel for your motorcycle to bandaging wounds and crafting makeshift weapons, every decision matters in the struggle for survival. Players can choose between stealthy approaches, utilizing tall grass and environmental distractions to evade enemies, or engaging in frenetic gunfights and melee combat. The game's responsive controls and varied arsenal of weapons allow for diverse playstyles, from silent assassinations to all-out assaults. One of the game's most exhilarating features is its dynamic Freaker horde system. These massive swarms of infected creatures roam the landscape, presenting a constant threat to players. Successfully confronting a Freaker horde requires careful planning, resource management, and split-second decision-making as players utilize traps, explosives, and environmental hazards to thin the horde's ranks before engaging in a desperate fight for survival.

From the lush forests and rugged mountains to the desolate ruins of civilization, every inch of the game is meticulously rendered with stunning detail and realism. Dynamic lighting effects, weather systems, and environmental textures combine to create a world that feels alive and evolving. Rainstorms, fog banks, and snowfall add layers of complexity to gameplay, impacting visibility, sound propagation, and enemy behavior.

Game employs dynamic sound effects to heighten tension and provide crucial feedback during gameplay. The roar of a motorcycle engine signals freedom and mobility, while the distinctive growls and shrieks of Freakers alert players to imminent danger. Gunshots echo across the landscape, signaling the start of intense firefights, while environmental cues such as creaking floorboards or snapping twigs warn of nearby threats. [h1] The Underdog That Battled All the Way Up!  [/h1]

From its tumultuous beginnings to its eventual rise as a cult classic, Days Gone has proven itself to be the dark horse of its genre, and, in my opinion, it's the game of the year within its class. This open-world adventure brings to the table an experience that is as heart-pounding as it is emotionally engaging, setting a new benchmark for narrative-driven survival horror games.

Soundtrack That Sets the Tone: One cannot simply talk about Days Gone without mentioning its brilliant soundtrack. The music in this game is nothing short of amazing, perfectly encapsulating the desolate yet beautiful landscapes of the Pacific Northwest. The atmospheric tunes elevate every ride through the abandoned roads and every tense encounter with the infected, making the game's world feel alive and teeming with unseen threats.

The Thrill of the Horde: Speaking of threats, the hordes in Days Gone are a standout feature. They bring a level of tension and excitement that is unmatched, creating moments of pure adrenaline as you strategise on the fly to survive the overwhelming numbers of the infected. The sight of a horde cascading down a hill like a tidal wave of death is something that stays with you, pushing you to refine your skills and come back stronger.

A Love-Hate Relationship with Screamers: Ah, the screamers! As much as I hate encountering these terrifying foes, I must admit they add a fun twist to the gameplay. Their ability to disrupt your plans and send you into a panic is paradoxically what makes them so enjoyable to outsmart. It's this balance of fear and fun that Days Gone nails so perfectly.

Characters That Stick With You: At the heart of Days Gone are its characters, and the arcs of Boozer and Deacon are particularly memorable. Watching their relationship evolve over the course of the game amidst the backdrop of a world gone mad is something truly special. The voice acting and character development are top-notch, making you care deeply about their fates and rooting for them every step of the way.

Hoping for More: As the credits rolled, I found myself both satisfied with the ending and yearning for more. Days Gone concludes on a high note, yet it leaves the door open for further exploration of its rich world. I join the chorus of fans eagerly hoping for a DLC or, even better, a Days Gone II. Bend Studio, if you're listening, know that your creation has left an indelible mark, and we're all waiting to see where you take us next.

In conclusion, Days Gone is more than just a game; it's a journey. A journey through a ravaged world that's as beautiful as it is dangerous. A journey with characters who feel like friends (and foes) we've known forever. To anyone on the fence about giving this game a try, I say go for it. You might just discover your next favorite game.

There aren't very many "outlaw" motorcycle games. LucasArts' Full Throttle was amazing in 1995, GTA4 The Lost and the Damned was pretty good (if short), GTA Online's Bikers stuff is okay. But there are almost no others that exist.

Days Gone is a great one for that Outlaw Biker vibe. 

The story is gripping, voice acting on point. Upgrading/customising the bike gives a great sense of progress. More to the point, the bike *feels* like riding a motorcycle.  Nearly every other motorcycle game feature crotch rockets. I want that lean-back LaZBoy feet up deep throttle rumble.

There isn't much for group riding like GTA's games. And I friggin' HATE zombies. I wouldn't normally *play* a game that had zombies as such a major component of the story, let alone the game. 

But Days Gone *felt* like being a lone biker making his way in a hostile -- and still beautiful -- environment, struggling between hope and cynicism, giving up on his humanity or doing the right thing. Imperfect, kind of a dick, but not, you know, a terrible person deep down. 

When the motorcycle is hibernating in storage, waiting for spring, Days Gone scratches that itch for me. Worth it.

Currently, Days Gone has to be in my top 10 games.

Yep, there are annoying bugs/flaws (as many people have mentioned), but even so… this game is excellent. If you are looking for a dystopian zombie open world, this is it. For all its flaws, the main reasons to get this game are… the graphics, story and world design. The feeling of “end of the world, with dangerous zombies” is captured perfectly here. It is fascinating to explore all the various locations and wonder “what if this ACTUALLY happened?”.

The flaws people mention are real: The policy of the developers to invade your privacy with their data capture? Shocking, and they should be called out for it, as others have done in their negative reviews. And the other major issue is, the Quality Assurance/Playtesting – yep, it’s bad. There are so many minor gameplay gripes/flaws/issues that you are left wondering if anyone actually did any playtesting. Watch the credits - literally dozens of people playtested this? Crazy. However, the annoying bugs are not enough to stop this from being an awesome experience.

The story and acting are really well done. The main plot between the male and female leads does take a strange turn about two-thirds of the way into the game, but overall, you do get completely invested in the characters and storyline. The supporting cast is excellent, and you will want to see what happens next.

A real standout part of the gameplay is the hordes of zombies. They really are truly terrifying. It’s rare to play a game these days and feel “on edge”, but trust me, as you approach a horde of 150 of these monsters, the adrenaline will be pumping.

Respect must be paid to the music and sound effects. The creepy build of the music as a zombie gets near you, or you approach a nest of them… man, it still gives me chills.

If you can get past the flaws, you can easily spend 60+ hours on this game. If the bugs had been sorted out, Days Gone would be a universal classic.

Reminds me a *LOT* of Mad Max (2015) PC game (also a very good game). Lots of ambushes, sneaking around and brutal fighting.  Except this has zombies, but just like the walking dead, they are generally less dangerous than living humans, save for in large hordes.

The combat is definitely tuned for a controller (originally came out for Playstation, so, yeah), and in games like this I almost prefer a controller for everything, except aiming weapons.  But for melee combat, driving, moving around and maneuvering across the landscape, a controller here is king.  I still use Mouse + Keyboard, however, as I'm too old to change my curmudgeony ways and refuse to aim a ranged weapon with the sticks.

My only real gripes with this game are there are no designated keys/buttons to swap back to your melee weapon.  The game takes this upon itself, assuming control of this selection when enemies get close enough, however this can be unreliable and inconsistent.  Is it so much to ask for the capability to bind my own key to select my melee weapon?  There is a sort of workaround: open your equipment wheel and select it that way.  This works, but it abjectly destroys the flow of a fight.

I'm playing this game, Mr. Game, not you, so stop making assumptions for me, mmkay?

All in all it's fun and worth playing if you enjoyed games like Mad Max (already mentioned), Shadows of Mordor, et al. Not saying this is a bad thing, but just so you know what to expect what kind of game this is.

Solid Game: 7.5/10
I Recommend picking it up on sale if you're not sure you may like this sort of game.

[h3]This review contains no spoilers.[/h3]
[b]Days Gone[/b] (DG) is a third-person action-adventure game set in a post-apocalyptic USA, two years after a pandemic transformed most people into monsters. [h1]In-Depth Analysis[/h1]
[h3]Pros[/h3]
[b]1.[/b]
Aside from the protagonist, also most of the side-characters Deacon meets in his adventures will have distinct, believable personalities that are in line with the times and events. In general, DG aims to depict a crude, violent world that sees the worst of human nature surface out of the sheer need for survival - and does so extremely well. The reactions, dialogue inflections, even expressions of most characters are consistent, realistic throughout the game.

[b]2.[/b]
From burning down mutant nests to eradicate infestations from whole chunks of the map, to re-activating pre-apocalypse technology or defeating bandit camps, there is a lot to do across the world. NPCs will periodically call for help in the form of quests as well, with some days having to pass between each call, in a realistic manner. Random events like summary executions to be stopped or skirmishes between factions happen quite often along the road, as well.

[b]3.[/b]
Between the meaty feeling of smashing enemies with a baseball bat, the satisfying thumping of bullets into heads, torsos and other appendages, or limbs flying after a close encounter with a pipe bomb, each fight in Days Gone proves really fun from start to end. Deception, stealth or even turning mutants against humans in cleverly-thought-out schemes are all possible solutions, other than the classic guns-blazing approach.

[b]4.[/b]
Deacon's arsenal, bike parts and passive skills can progressively become better, thanks to an XP-based leveling system and a reputation system in allied encampments. As one completes side-activities or quests, more and more new weapons, parts and gadgets will be unlocked to either purchase or craft. Some quest-lines give unique weapons or blueprints as well along the way or at full completion - so it's worth investing time in doing everything.

[b]5.[/b]
A special mention needs to be done for Horde fights, where Deacon will find himself against hundreds of mutants at a time. The gameplay of such encounters is a thing onto itself, partially puzzle and partially a test of strategy. Using choke-points, narrow spaces, environmental elements like explosive barrels, distractions and a whole lot of bullets will all come together beautifully, to decide one's victory or defeat.

[h3]Cons[/h3]
[b]1.[/b]
The good variety of approaches and activities simply isn't enough to keep the game fresh all the way to the end. After about 30-35 hours at best, most players will have acquired powerful weapons, advanced bike pieces and many useful passive skills, while the mission types won't change and be always the same. Expect, for the last third of the total playtime, the gameplay to become much more repetitive and bland.

[b]2.[/b]
From hordes not being shown on the global map until very late game, when they would be totally feasible and needed before, to the inability to save without being close to the bike or a bed, there are some annoyances that make the experience worse. The fact Survival difficulty disables fast travel, adding hours of useless filler time spent travelling "manually" to get anywhere, is a depressing design choice.

[b]3.[/b]
Fellow humans like bandits or cultists, despite having guns, bombs and armors, prove to be much less of a threat than mutants. This mainly happens because their AI isn't exactly bright: their aim is generally subpar, the tactics suicidal, and the reaction times on the slow side. While some human enemies can be dangerous, most of them can be dispatched with a headshot before they can do anything.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2524211036

[h1]Gameplay Breakdown[/h1]

[b]Exploration[/b]
Is performed on foot or, for long distances, with Deacon's custom bike, which will need to be periodically refueled and repaired. The world is large, and houses dozens of points of interest to uncover. Fast-travel is possible to friendly camps, however only if the bike has enough fuel, while it's disabled on Survival difficulty. Most of the world won't be accessible initially, as the main quests will need to progress in order to unlock more areas.

[b]Combat[/b]
Is done in either melee or ranged fashion, using a good array of murder tools such as spiked baseball bats, hatchets, assault rifles, grenades, napalm and everything in-between. A well-placed headshot can dispatch all but the strongest mutants in one hit, and one the higher difficulties just a few punches from a regular mutant will be enough to bring Deacon down at least until mid-late game. Using cover against humans and their guns, while being quick and agile against melee-only mutants or animals will be the main approaches to fights. Deacon can use Focus to slow time considerably and land accurate shots, but for a very small time.

[b]Character Management[/b]
Is performed mainly at camps and safe zones, where a gun locker to swap weapons, stalls to sell mutant parts for money and various vendors to acquire new gear, ammo and consumables are present. Deacon's bike can be heavily modded with better parts, that however just like guns and other stuff, need a certain reputation with that particular camp to be purchased. These bike mods can be vital to reach some hidden loot stashes or upgrades, or just get things done faster. The skills panel allows Deacon to spend skill points to enhance three different trees focused on ranged, melee and survival abilities.

[b]Challenge Mode[/b]
Is a separate mode that pits Deacon against specifically-designed scenarios, with main and side objectives to complete. The better he performs, the higher the rating will be, in turn awarding cash to spend in unlock new weapons, skills and bonuses for the next challenge, in sort of a "roguelite" fashion.

I don't really know what I should say about this game, or where I should start. The reason is that I want to keep this review as short as possible, because this game is heavily story focused and besides the story it doesn't offer much.
Now hold on... Before you think that I mean this in a negative way... No I don't! Let me tell you now ... The story is totally worth it! 

This Review also, doesn't contain any spoilers, so you don't have to be afraid to read this whole Textwall.

First of it is an "Open World" with great looking visuals. Even if you play it on medium or low settings, the game will still look good. The optimization of the port is top and the framerate will always stay at a high rate. Animations, character design and the design of the open world (valleys, villages, farms, ....) is just on point. You can even check out many reallife monuments and the game even tells you about their history and the history of the country. But besides this, there is nothing much to explore. One abandoned house looks like the other and there is not much loot to get.

I already said that this game is heavily story focused. Even the sidequests tell a small connected story and add much to the overall atmosphere. Just be warned that some sidequests are getting repeated once in while, but they always have a small story behind them which makes them interesting again. 
You will find many very well written characters. Some of them are your average "The Walking Dead" characters, but this doesn't mean they are not interesting. Talking about "TWD" .. This whole game feels like a whole season. To be precise: A "TWD" season between 1 and 5 (before the writing got odd). I am not going to say anything about the story, because even the smallest things might reveal something. I just say that it is perfectly executed and will keep you going until you beat it.

There is a crafting system, but it isn't as demanding as in any other open world titles and it is mostly simplified. Many people criticize it, but I like it the way it is. You have a pipe, gunpowder and stuff? Just craft a pipebomb in less than a second to blow up some zombies.

Zombies .... Or Freaker. That is another thing. I love their mechanic and how they work. In most zombie games the zombies are all still intelligent at some point. In this game they aren't. They are stupid and this is good. They will run after you and ignore any obstacles. The more they are the more dangerous they get. Up until you randomly meet a horde (They are not scripted by the way and you can just stumble across them.). They are strong and they will always be strong. You might level up, but you are not going to be overpowered at any point. Hordes stay scary until the end of the game and it is sometimes even better to just run or take your bike and get the hell out.

The bike is another feature of this game. It is excellently made. First of ... yes ... The bike is your only ride, but this gets explained very early on. The streets are full with cars and the tundra can also only be accessed with a bike. We are talking about a time where it is way better and way more easier to get from A to B with a fast vehicle and not a big bulky car. You will just notice that you have to get gas once in a while. [h3]”Nothing says true love like dog skulls”[/h3]
Days Gone is an open-world post-apocalyptic zombie game with survival elements. It's a LONG game. At the time of this review, the 68.7 hours I have in the game is a single playthrough doing only the main story with a fair number of extras.

You'll take the role of Deacon St. John, an abrasive character for sure. The game throws you not only into an active virus outbreak that leads to a zombie apocalypse, but into Deacon's relationships with a number of people. People he seems to not have the greatest history with — “burned bridges”. He's also stuck on his lost love, two sentiments I identify with more than I care to admit in my real life. Ultimately, this makes him slightly unlikable. That combined with the game's length makes this a game for people looking for a certain experience.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3144447687

[h3]My bike, my bike, my kingdom for my bike![/h3]
Being reductive, this game feels a lot like Death Stranding meets Far Cry. But I don't think it would be inappropriate to draw comparisons to Red Dead Redemption 2. 

Your bike is your lifeline. It's how you travel, it's how you save. It will literally save your life. Fast travel is allowed if you have the gas and the path is not obstructed by things like infestation zones. Otherwise you need to get around without it. The bike does need gas to function but this is relatively trivial as an aspect of the game's survival traits. For one, gas cans respawn and do not run out of gas. And gas pumps are still active in this time, it's only been a few years. When I first started playing, I became rather anxious thinking I'd need to be constantly concerned about gas. You're always getting something as well. Killing stray zombies (freaks) or marauders will earn you XP to upgrade Deacon's abilities. The freak ears and other zombie types can also be sold to camps for credits and that will also build trust. 

You do need to be careful however, ambushes can happen out of the blue. Not only this, but the gunfire or explosions can cause more freaks or non-infected wildlife to show up. Wolves, bears, mountain lions. The game can go from 0 to 100 real fast.

Your bike can be upgraded upon building trust with camps. As a drifter, you're able to go out on missions for a number of camps and establish more trust within them. You'll earn both trust (a type of XP really) and camp credits to refill things like ammo. Other resources can be pilfered out in the wild. You'll learn where to find certain types of resources as well — scrap can be found in almost any vehicle if the hood is still shut, gas cans are usually found around industrial vehicles such as tow trucks. Ammo can usually be found in police vehicles, medkits in ambulances — things you'd expect. 

Much like Death Stranding, while you aren't a “Porter”, you are effectively playing that same role within this world. You'll learn the map and better ways to navigate it to perform the tasks the camps want. Bounty hunting, horde killing, resource retrieval and more.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3144447046

There's also a bit of conspiracy if you investigate the NERO checkpoints and go down that path. 

[h3]The Gist[/h3]
I think this game appeals to a rather specific audience. It does have multiple endings and there's a TON to do in this game. Granted, it can be a tad grindy. But the gunplay is great, the bike riding is great and I personally identified with Deacon in a number of ways. More prudently, if you feel... lost in your real life, this game might be the exact thing you need to distract yourself for a time.

For another, Days Gone is at its core a working-class love story. Two kinds of love, that is: love between a man and a woman, and love between two brothers. It is completely and utterly unapologetic on both fronts. There's no ironic Joss Whedon distancing here. It's about ordinary people who love each other and fight to make it through the shit the world throws at you.

As a writer, one of the things I particularly admire is that the game takes it time. By the time you reach the southern part of the map, you've gone through an entire emotional arc. You really get to spend time with the characters as they go through their lives in the apocalypse. And the characters, including your own, evolve. They make mistakes. They become better people. Crucially, they try to actually do things that make the world a better place. By the end, it feels like you've lived through something real.

The superb voice acting and excellent cutscene animations help with that, of course. And the writing itself, on a line to line level, is fantastic. So many memorable moments and characters. That it's rooted in a real place and in the lives of working-class people makes it infinitely more compelling.

Gameplay-wise, the game avoids many of the frustrating aspects of AAA open-world games. It's not a just a pretty but hollow world to walk around while you complete generic activities. One of the things I yearn for is games that make you learn to live in their world (the STALKER games do this, as does Far Cry Primal, especially at higher difficulties). I want games that make you live the fantasy of their subject matter. Days Gone is all about that: you have to take care of your motorcycle, look for fuel, watch how you move about the world, look out for hordes, etc. Yes, it can be slow and in some sense "grindy" but to me that's part of the joy. I don't mind stopping for fuel, or collecting materials so I can craft a bomb to blow up a horde with. I'm playing a biker in a terrifying apocalypse, not a superhero.

Speaking of the hordes, they are terrifying, and the fact that they move about the map adds wonderfully to the immersion. Figuring out how to deal with them, especially early on, is thrilling and rewarding.

Days Gone deserved so much better, including a sequel to carry the story forward. (But don't worry, it doesn't end in a frustrating way. It doesn't try to be "clever" by taking away the achievements of the characters with some cynical twist - it just points to the next thing the world is going to throw at them.) I rarely find games that really mean something to me anymore. Sometimes I think that I've completely lost faith in the medium. Then I find something like Days Gone and remember what amazing experiences games can be. It's probably not for everyone, but it's 100% for me.

After +60 hours gameplay, Days Gone is a really good and underappreciated game. 

Despite an underwhelming first couple of hours, the game grew on me more and more as the world opened up, as I got accustomed the the gameplay loop and once I'd put a few points into slo-mo shooting. The reason for the latter is that the freakers really dodge about everywhere and it gets frustrating to miss shots and then end up in melee; the weaker, less enjoyable side of combat.

After that, it just picked up. I loved surviving out in the unforgiving world of Days Gone. I enjoyed the combination of stealth and gunplay. I enjoyed being able to switch between the two and the variety in combat situations the monsters and the bandits.

The side quests often have on-going stories for the npc's involved and they are dished out at regular intervals, meaning you can't just blow through one person's questline only to have them disappear for the rest of the game. Instead, by spreading things out, you get to catch up on them now and then as time passes in the main story, which keeps things feeling natural.

The hordes are great. Early on, they're terrifying hazards and, even late game, a force to be reckoned with but, as Deacon gets stronger and better equipped, you'll slowly start to turn the tide.

Whilst nothing Days Gone does is new or done to a level beyond anything that has come before, it does enough things well enough, with enough care and heart , for most of it to be enjoyable and varied.

The exact ebb and flow of the gameplay loop is down to you, the player, so it's great to do things as and when the mood takes you.

The main story has a surprising amount of twists and turns, even if it is sometimes uneven in quality. Most of the main npc's have strong(Iron Mike, Boozer, Rikki etc.), well-defined characters and the overall tone of the world has a good amount of moral ambiguity to it. What people have to do to survive, the decisions they have to make...the game tries to show people with all their imperfections and it's more interesting for it than a lot of what I see in games these days.

Weapons have a good amount of variety, they definitely feel different and have pros and cons meaning choosing the right ones for the right job requires at least a bit of thought. Upgrading Deke brings noticeable, satisfying and rewarding benefits.

The bike being your save point is a great idea. On harder difficulty settings, you genuinely feel vulnerable when you stash it somewhere to go explore or scavenge.

Deacon's character takes a bit of getting used to. He's a grumpy, messed up guy, but you can feel he's trying to change as he finally comes to terms with the reality that he's let this bleak world break his spirit - leaving him living a pointless life.

The way the backstory of Deacon is told is well done in terms of the segments but sometimes jarring given that it's often telling you stuff in reverse order, or simply a jumbled up order.

For example, someone close to Deacon says something really cringe worthy at one point. It's bizarre and out of character. 'What a crap bit of script', I thought. However, some time after another flashback, which goes back in time from the previous one, explains why this is. It then made sense and put a smile on my face but that doesn't change the fact that the initial flashback seemed poorly written at the time. It's an odd choice and sometimes it didn't work for me.

The map is surprisingly big as it expands 3 times from the initial area you start in. I think my first playthrough was close to 40 hours. I also appreciated the fact that after the main story is finished, there are 3-4 questlines that have one or two extra bits; to tie up loose ends with some of the npc's you've gotten to know along the way. Plus, there's an extra piece of story if you defeat all the hordes...it really set things up nicely (and ominously) for a sequel so I was very disappointed to hear Sony didn't give it the greenlight. I strongly believe it deserves a sequel, I'd love to see this concept expanded upon and made better.
